questions.question: A 5-year-old boy presents with severe, chronic diarrhoea, failure to thrive, and a rash. His medical history includes a diagnosis of type 1 diabetes mellitus and thyroiditis. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of anti-enterocyte antibodies. Based on these findings, which mechanism is most likely impaired in this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Peripheral tolerance Explanation: The clinical scenario likely describes IPEX (immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, X-linked) due to defective peripheral tolerance. IPEX is an X-linked immune dysregulation disorder that presents in childhood. It occurs due to defects in the FOXP3 gene, which plays a crucial role in peripheral tolerance mediated by CD4+ T regulatory cells. Defects in FOXP3 lead to dysfunctional CD4+ T regulatory cells, impairing their ability to maintain immune tolerance and resulting in autoimmune reactions against various tissues, particularly within the gastrointestinal tract. It has a classic triad of: Enteropathy (chronic diarrhoea due to intestinal inflammation) Polyendocrinopathy (m/c - Type I DM and thyroiditis) Dermatitis (eczematous) Defective central tolerance (Option A) may cause autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome (APS) due to a mutation in the AIRE gene, which is characterized by chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis, abnormalities of skin, dental enamel, and nails (ectodermal dystrophy), autoimmune adrenalitis, autoimmune hypoparathyroidism, idiopathic hypogonadism, pernicious anaemia. Anergy (Option C) is a tolerance mechanism in which lymphocytes are intrinsically functionally inactivated following an antigen encounter. Induction of anergy can be helpful in the treatment of autoimmune diseases and allergies. It has no role in IPEX. Hidden (Option D) antigen refers to antigens from sites not accessed by the body’s regular immune system. These include the brain (separated by the blood-brain barrier), the testes, and the eye. Disruption of these barriers can result in respective organ dysfunction. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 217, 1123 https://www.uptodate.com/contents/ipex-immune-dysregulation-polyendocrinopathy-enteropathy-x-linked

questions.question: Match the following processes in immune tolerance with their associated regulators. Process Regulators 1. Negative selection a. CD-28 2. Anergy b. FOXP3 3. Deletion by apoptosis c. AIRE 4. Suppression by regulatory T cells d. CD95
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A): 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b. Explanation: Negative selection or clonal deletion : Process in which T cells expressing receptors for self-antigens encounter these antigens in the thymus and are then killed by apoptosis. AIRE (autoimmune regulator) is a regulator protein critical for deleting these T cells. A defect in AIRE leads to autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome. Anergy : A process where lymphocytes that recognise self-antigens are rendered functionally unresponsive. Binding co-stimulatory signals to CD28 leads to T cell proliferation and differentiation. CTLA-4 is an inhibitory receptor on T cells that prevents CD28-mediated costimulation of T cells. Deletion by apoptosis : T cells that recognise self-antigens receive signals that promote their death by apoptosis. Upon recognition of self-antigens, lymphocytes express the death receptor Fas (CD95) . Mutations in Fas or FasL result in autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome (ALPS) Suppression by regulatory T cells : CD4+/ regulatory T cells prevent immune reactions against self-antigens. Both IL-2 and FOXP3 are required for the functioning of CD4+ regulatory T cells. Mutations in FOXP3 result in an autoimmune disease called IPEX (immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, X-linked ). Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 216-217, 219

questions.question: Which of the following is an immune-privileged site?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Testis Explanation: Among the given options, the testis is an immune-privileged site. The testis, eye, and brain are called immune-privileged sites because antigens are sequestered from the immune system without communicating with blood and lymph. Brain Blood-brain barrier Eyes Blood-ocular barrier Testes Blood-testicular barrier These tissues fail to elicit immune responses and are ignored by the immune system. If the antigens of these tissues are released as a consequence of trauma or infection, an immune response will result, leading to prolonged inflammation and injury. This is the postulated mechanism for post-traumatic orchitis and uveitis. Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 217-218

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman presents with a history of fatigue, fever, and weight loss. She also reports joint pain, swelling and a rash, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Systemic Lupus Erythematosus Explanation: The patient's clinical presentation suggests systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease with the production of many antibodies like antinuclear antibodies (ANAs), anti-double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) and anti-Smith (Sm) These autoantibodies form immune complexes that deposit in tissues, causing inflammation and damage. It is more common in women. Clinical Manifestations of SLE: Skin: Malar rash (butterfly rash), photosensitivity, discoid lesions, and mucosal ulcers. Joints: Non-erosive arthritis commonly affects the hands, wrists, and knees. Renal: Lupus nephritis ranging from asymptomatic proteinuria to severe kidney failure. The major cause of morbidity and mortality in SLE. Cardiovascular: Pericarditis, myocarditis, increased risk of atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease. Pulmonary: Pleurisy and pleural effusion, pulmonary hypertension and interstitial lung. Neurologic: Neuropsychiatric symptoms ranging from headaches and cognitive dysfunction to seizures and psychosis. Hematologic: Anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. The risk of thrombotic events is increased. Dermatomyositis (Option A) can present with skin rash, muscle weakness, and occasionally joint pain, but it typically lacks the malar rash seen in SLE. questions.question: A 19-year-old woman presents with malaise, joint pain, and fever for the past 3 months. Physical examination shows a malar rash and mouth ulcers. She has significant proteinuria and decreased GFR. Which of the following antibodies are most specific and most sensitive, respectively?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Anti-Sm, ANA Explanation: Based on the above clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are the hallmark of the disease. Positive ANA is seen in >97% of cases of SLE. However, it has low specificity and is seen in healthy individuals and many other diseases. Anti-Smith(Sm) antibodies are seen in less than 30% of SLE patients but have 99% specificity for SLE. Anti-double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) antibodies have more than 95% specificity. Serum titers of an anti-dsDNA correlate with disease activity and the development of lupus nephritis. Marker/Antibody Clinical Significance Anti-Smith (anti-Sm) antibodies Highly specific for SLE (<30% of patients) Anti-dsDNA antibodies Highly specific for SLE (60-70% of patients); correlates with the disease Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) Highly sensitive but not specific for SLE Anti-Ro (SSA) and Anti-La (SSB) antibodies Found in SLE and Sjögren syndrome; associated with neonatal lupus Anti-ribosomal-P antibodies Specific for neuropsychiatric manifestations in SLE Anti-histone antibodies Seen in drug-induced lupus; less specific for SLE Complements C3 and C4 Low levels indicate complement consumption and disease activity Reference: Robbins and Cotran's Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 222 Systemic Lupus Erythematosus - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov) Autoantibodies in SLE: Specificities, Isotypes and Receptors - PMC (nih.gov)

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman with SLE complains of red, frothy urine for the past two months despite being on treatment. Urine analysis shows RBCs and proteins. An image of renal biopsy is given below. Which of the following accurately describes the histopathological findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Wire loop lesions Explanation: Wire loop lesions are a characteristic histopathological finding in lupus nephritis. 50% of SLE patients have clinically significant renal involvement SLE can cause six patterns of glomerular disease: Class Name Description I Minimal mesangial nephritis Immune complex deposition in the mesangium, identified by immunofluorescence and by electron microscopy, but without structural changes by light microscopy. II Mesangial proliferative nephritis Mesangial cell proliferation is often accompanied by mesangial matrix accumulation, granular mesangial immunoglobulin deposits, and complement without the involvement of glomerular capillaries. III Focal nephritis Involvement of <50% of glomeruli. The lesions may be segmental (affecting only a portion of the glomerulus) or global (involving the entire glomerulus). Affected glomeruli may exhibit swelling and proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells, leukocyte accumulation, capillary necrosis, and hyaline thrombi. questions.question: A 55-year-old woman has had persistent dry eyes and mouth for the past several months. She also reports difficulty in swallowing solid foods and occasional blurred vision. On examination, she has bilateral parotid gland enlargement. She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis. Which antibodies are specific for this disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Anti La Explanation: Based on the above clinical scenario, the patient can be diagnosed with Sjogren’s syndrome. Autoantibodies against SS-A (Ro) and SS-B (La) antigens are serologic markers of Sjogren’s syndrome. It can be an isolated disorder (primary form), aka sicca syndrome, or association with another autoimmune disease (secondary form) like rheumatoid arthritis, SLE, polymyositis, scleroderma, vasculitis, mixed connective tissue disease, etc. There is immunological destruction of the lacrimal and salivary glands, resulting in keratoconjunctivitis sicca and xerostomia. Symptoms include blurred vision, difficulty swallowing, decreased taste, cracks and fissures in the mouth, and parotid gland enlargement. Extra glandular manifestations can include synovitis, diffuse pulmonary fibrosis, peripheral neuropathy, and renal tubular acidosis. Autoantibody Associated Autoimmune Condition Anti-Sm (Smith) (Option A) Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) Anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase I) (Option C) Diffuse systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) Anti-U1 RNP (Ribonucleoprotein) (Option D) Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD) Reference: Robbins and Cotran's Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 230

questions.question: A 20-year-old female complains of recurrent episodes of her fingers turning symmetrically white, which are associated with pain and a tingling sensation. This is worse when exposed to cold water and is relieved when she dips her fingers in warm water. The autoimmune panel is negative. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Primary Raynaud phenomenon Explanation: The given clinical scenario describes the Raynaud phenomenon (an exaggerated vasoconstriction of arteries and arterioles in response to cold or emotional stress. The fingers classically show red, white, and blue colour changes from most proximal to most distal, correlating with proximal vasodilation, central vasoconstriction, and more distal cyanosis. Untreated RP may result in ulceration and, in severe cases, autoamputation. Primary Raynaud's phenomenon is characterized by symmetric episodes of finger whitening induced by cold, resulting from hyper reactive smooth muscle cells in the blood vessel walls. It occurs without an underlying disorder and typically does not lead to ulcers. Tests for autoimmune conditions yield negative results in such cases. Secondary Raynaud's phenomenon results from underlying arterial disease seen in autoimmune disorders like mixed connective tissue disease, CREST syndrome, and SLE. It shows asymmetric finger involvement and progressive worsening of symptoms over time. (Option C) Dermatomyositis (Option B) may involve the hands, with classical lesions being Gottron papules (multiple hyperkeratotic, flat, red papules over the dorsum of the metacarpophalangeal joints) and mechanic hands (fissuring with hyperkeratotic papules, scaling, and fissures along the sides of the fingers and palms). Calcinosis cutis (Option D) is a characteristic lesion of CREST syndrome, referring to the deposition of calcific nodules in the skin of the hands.

questions.question: A 60-year-old woman complains of bilateral hand pain and stiffness, especially in the morning. On examination, you notice diffuse thickening and tightening of the skin all over her body. Echo showed pulmonary hypertension. Laboratory tests show positive Anti-SCL-70 antibodies What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Systemic sclerosis Explanation: The patient's presentation and echo showing pulmonary hypertension are highly suggestive of systemic sclerosis, also known as scleroderma. Scleroderma, also known as systemic sclerosis, is a rare autoimmune disease characterized by excessive collagen production, which leads to thickening and hardening of the skin and other organs. It is predominantly seen in females and has a peak incidence in the 50-60 age group. Localized scleroderma primarily affects the skin, typically confined to areas such as the fingers, forearms, and face, while systemic sclerosis involves both skin and internal organs. Subtypes In systemic sclerosis: Limited systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome) features calcinosis, Raynaud phenomenon, oesophagal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia. It is characterized by a positive anti-centromere antibody (option C) Diffuse systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) features widespread skin thickening starting from fingers, positive Anti-SCL-70 antibody, and extensive organ involvement: GIT dysfunction, musculoskeletal inflammation, scleroderma renal crisis, interstitial lung fibrosis, pulmonary hypertension, and cardiac manifestations. Rheumatoid arthritis (Option A) : This condition is characterized by symmetrical joint pain and swelling and is distinguished by the presence of rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide. Osteoarthritis (Option B) is a degenerative joint disease affecting weight-bearing joints without skin involvement or autoimmune features. Reference: Robbins and Cotran's Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 231 Systemic Sclerosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive proximal muscle weakness over the past 6 months. On examination, the hip and shoulder girdle muscles have symmetrical weakness. Laboratory investigations show elevated serum creatine kinase (CK) levels. A muscle biopsy reveals endomysial inflammation with CD8+ T lymphocytes and muscle fiber necrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Polymyositis Explanation The features of progressive proximal muscle weakness along with the findings of endomysial inflammation on biopsy suggest the diagnosis of polymyositis. Polymyositis: Polymyositis is an adult-onset inflammatory myopathy. Pathogenesis: Unknown, but it is believed to have an immunologic basis. CD8+ cytotoxic T cells are the mediators of tissue damage. Endomysial inflammation is seen and no atrophy. Dermatomyositis (Option A) also presents with proximal muscle weakness and elevated CK levels, but it typically includes skin manifestations (e.g., heliotrope rash, Gottron's papules), which are not mentioned here. Muscle biopsy in dermatomyositis typically shows perifascicular atrophy with CD4+ T cells, rather than the endomysial inflammation and CD8+ T cells seen in polymyositis. Myasthenia Gravis (Option B) commonly presents with fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and typically involves ocular muscles (ptosis, diplopia) early on, which are not described here. Diagnosis is based on clinical history, physical findings, identification of anti-ACh receptor autoantibodies, and electrophysiologic studies. Inclusion Body Myositis (IBM) (Option C) can affect the quadriceps and the distal upper extremity muscles commonly with elevated CK levels, especially in older adults. questions.question: A 32-year-old woman presents with fatigue, muscle weakness, and joint pain. On examination, she has a rash over her cheeks, along with Raynaud's phenomenon and swollen fingers. Laboratory tests reveal positive anti-U1 RNP antibodies. Which of the following conditions is this patient most likely suffering from?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Mixed connective tissue disease Explanation: Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD) is characterised by a combination of features, including muscle weakness, joint pain, a rash over the cheeks (often referred to as a butterfly rash), Raynaud's phenomenon, and anti-U1 RNP antibodies. MCTD features overlap between systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma (systemic sclerosis), and polymyositis . It is characterised by synovitis in the fingers, Raynaud's phenomenon, myositis, and mild renal involvement. Over time, MCTD may progress to classic systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or systemic sclerosis. Antibody: Anti U1 RNP (ribonucleoprotein) antibody. Treatment: Corticosteroids. Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 234

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman is being evaluated for proximal muscle weakness. Which of the following is consistent with a diagnosis of polymyositis?

options.A: CD4+ T cell infiltration in affected tissue

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Endomysial inflammation Explanation: Endomysial inflammation is a consistent feature of polymyositis. Polymyositis is an inflammatory myopathy that typically presents with proximal muscle weakness. It is mediated by a CD8+ T cell response to endogenous MHC antigens and vascular injury does not have a major role in its pathogenesis. (Option B and D) Primary symptoms of polymyositis include proximal muscle weakness impairing activities like raising arms, climbing stairs, or standing from a seated position. Esophageal muscle weakness may cause dysphagia and cardiac involvement can lead to arrhythmias and heart failure. Histologically, it is characterized by an endomysial inflammatory infiltrate with patchy necrosis. Dermatomyositis It presents with symmetric proximal muscle weakness, skin rash, and extramacular manifestations, such as oesophagal dysfunction and interstitial lung disease. Skin rash- Heliotrope rash, Gottron's papules, necklace sign, shawl sign, mechanic hands. Its pathogenesis is believed to be secondary to vasculopathy mediated by CD4+ T cells. Positive for anti-Mi2, anti-Jo1 and anti- SRP antibodies Histologic findings include peri fascicular infiltrates and atrophy in a segmental pattern. questions.question: A 28-year-old female presents with fatigue, joint pain, and a rash. A blood test reveals positive anti-nuclear antibodies. Which of the following fluorescence patterns is most commonly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)? A. B. C. D.
questions.explanation: associated with SLE, reflecting uniform nucleus staining. The most widely used method for detecting ANAs is indirect immunofluorescence, which can identify antibodies that bind to a variety of nuclear antigens, including DNA, RNA, and proteins (collectively called generic ANAs). The pattern of nuclear fluorescence suggests the type of antibody present in the patient’s serum. Four basic patterns are recognized Homogeneous or diffuse staining of nuclei (Option A) Antibodies reactive with dsDNA, nucleosomes, and histones, and is common in systemic lupus erythematosus Speckled pattern (Option B) Antibodies against various nuclear antigens, including Sm and RNPs Nucleolar pattern (Option C) Antibodies against nucleolar proteins Anti-centromere antibodies (Option D) Systemic sclerosis, Sjögren syndrome, and other diseases

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of dermatomyositis? A. B. C. D.
questions.explanation: diseases like erythema nodosum. Dermatomyositis: An inflammatory myopathy that affects skin as well as skeletal muscles. Proximal muscles will be involved. Characteristic rashes include: Heliotrope rash (Option C) - Erythematous discoloration of eyelids with periorbital edema. Gottron papules (Option A) - Raised erythematous rash over knuckles V-sign (Necklace sign) - Rash on the sun-exposed anterior neck and chest. Shawl sign over the back of the neck and shoulders. Mechanic hands (Option D) - Presence of cracked hands. Nail bed changes with dilated capillaries. The histological hallmark of dermatomyositis: Perifascicular atrophy (Atrophy of the muscle fibers which are located at the periphery). The following autoantibodies are associated with specific complications and findings: Anti-Jo: Antisynthetase syndrome consisting of interstitial lung disease, mechanic's hands, Raynaud phenomenon, sclerodactyly, and arthritis. Anti-Mi2 (directed against helicase): Acute onset disease, V-neck sign, and shawl rash. Anti-MDA5 (melanoma differentiation-associated gene 5): Severe cutaneous involvement, amyopathic dermatomyositis, and rapidly progressive ILD. Anti-TIF-1 gamma (transcription intermediary factor) /Anti-p155/140: Malignancy. Anti-NXP2 (nuclear matrix protein 2): Calcinosis cutis.
